claims.text: 5G WiFi networks could be responsible for the rapid spread of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. There is no evidence that 5G WiFi networks are linked to the new coronavirus.

claims.text: Cleveland Clinic developed a Covid-19 test that gives results in hours, not days.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The clinic announced that it is able to speed up Covid-19 testing after developing the ability to test on-site, but it had not developed a new test.

claims.text: All seven patients who were getting treated for Covid-19 at Safdarjung hospital in New Delhi have recovered.

claimReview.textualRating: There is a news story reporting that seven patients in this hospital in New Delhi had recovered. However, these were not the only Covid-19 patients in the city.

claims.text: Plasma from newly recovered patients from Covid -19 can treat others infected by Covid-19.

claimReview.textualRating: This is being used as a treatment in some countries, but clinical trials have not yet proved that this is effective.

claims.text: China has closed down its last coronavirus hospital. Not enough new cases to support them.

claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The last hospitals closed at the start of March 2020.

claims.text: A 103 year-old Chinese grandmother has made a full recovery from Covid-19 after being treated for 6 days in Wuhan, China

claimReview.textualRating: This has been widely reported in the media.

claims.text: A San Diego biotech company is developing a Covid-19 vaccine in collaboration with Duke University and National University of Singapore.

claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The company, Arcturus Therapeutics, announced on 4 March 2020 that it would be working on a vaccine with DukeNUS Medical School in Singapore.

claims.text: The number of new cases in South Korea is declining.

claimReview.textualRating: This was correct when the viral post began to appear. Reported new cases declined from their peak in late February, and have been roughly level since mid-March

claims.text: Scientists in Israel are likely to announce the development of a coronavirus vaccine.

claimReview.textualRating: Scientists in Israel and elsewhere are working on developing a vaccination to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus, but it won’t be ready for the public for over a year.

claims.text: Doctors in India have been successful in treating coronavirus with a combination of drugs (Lopinavir, Retonovir, Oseltamivir along with Chlorphenamine) and are going to suggest the same medicine globally.

claimReview.textualRating: India’s ministry of health has advised that the anti-HIV drugs, Lopinavir and Retonovir, are used in some groups of Covid-19 patients. But it is unclear how successful this treatment has been. The other two drugs from the claim are not mentioned in their guidance.

claims.text: Three Maryland coronavirus patients fully recovered and are able to return to everyday life.

claimReview.textualRating: Correct. On 13 March 2020, Montgomery County, Maryland confirmed that three residents who previously had the virus no longer tested positive.

claims.text: A network of Canadian scientists are making excellent progress in Covid-19 research.

claimReview.textualRating: At least one group of Canadian scientists has recently announced some progress in understanding Covid-19.

claims.text: Italy is hit hard, experts say, only because they have the oldest population in Europe.

claimReview.textualRating: Whilst it is true that an older population has contributed to a high number of deaths in Italy, it may not be the sole reason.

claims.text: Tulsa County's first positive Covid-19 case has recovered. This individual has had two negative tests, which is the indicator of recovery.

claimReview.textualRating: Correct, this patient has recovered according to official Tulsa County sources. Two negative tests is one of three official indicators of recovery among people with Covid-19 (who showed symptoms).

claims.text: Apple has reopened all 42 China stores.

claimReview.textualRating: Correct. On 13 March 2020, Apple announced that it had reopened all 42 stores in mainland China after a closure of almost six weeks.

claims.text: Researchers at the Erasmus Medical Center claim to have found an antibody against coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: Researchers in the Netherlands have released research, which has not yet been peer-reviewed, on an antibody against the new coronavirus.

claims.text: The television show "My Secret Terrius" predicted the 2020 COVID-19 outbreak.

claimReview.title: Did the TV Show 'My Secret Terrius' Predict Coronavirus?

claims.text: Coronavirus has been "found in crab leg."

claimReview.title: Coronavirus Hasn't Contaminated Crab Legs

claims.text: Coronavirus issues were because "we were given rules, regulations, and specifications from a different time."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: "I have waived interest that all student loans held by federal government agencies, and that will be until further notice."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: "Google is helping to develop a website, it’s going to be very quickly done, unlike websites of the past, to determine whether a test is warranted and to facilitate testing at a nearby convenient location.”

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: "Europe was just designated as the hot spot right now and we closed that border a while ago."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: "If you go back to the swine flu, it was nothing like this. They didn’t do testing like this."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: On disbanding the White House's pandemic team: "I didn’t do it. We have a group of people I could ask — perhaps my administration — but I could perhaps ask Tony about that because I don’t know anything about it."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: "Telehealth, a fairly new and incredible thing that has happened in the not-so-distant past."

claimReview.title: Trump's False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus

claims.text: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses. Try not to drink liquids with ice.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can either protect you from or cure diseases caused by viruses.

claims.text: If the new coronavirus gets into your mouth, drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through the oesophagus. Once they’re in the stomach, the acid will kill the virus. If you don't drink enough water more regularly, the virus can enter your windpipes and into the lungs.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Drinking water does not prevent an infection.

claims.text: You should also gargle as a prevention. A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this works as a preventative or a cure for the virus.

claims.text: Coronavirus pneumonia is a dry cough with no runny nose.

claimReview.textualRating: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: If someone with the new coronavirus sneezes, it travels about 10 feet before it drops to the ground and is no longer airborne.

claimReview.textualRating: How far the droplets spread from a sneeze depends on environmental factors, but it is likely to be several metres.

claims.text: This new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of just 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claims.text: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold, not Covid-19.

claimReview.textualRating: These are the symptoms for the common cold, but they don’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: On fabric it can survive for 6-12 hours. normal laundry detergent will kill it.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence yet that the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way. Any soiled clothing should be thoroughly washed.

claims.text: To test for the new coronavirus, take a deep breath and hold for more than 10 seconds. If you complete it successfully without coughing, discomfort, stuffiness or tightness it proves there is no fibrosis in the lungs, basically indicating no infection.

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this test can show if you have the new coronavirus.

claims.text: Wash your hands frequently as the virus can only live on your hands for 5-10 minutes.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can last on the skin, especially not down to the minute. But you should regularly wash your hands.

claims.text: If it drops on a metal surface it will live for at least 12 hours - so if you come into contact with any metal surface - wash your hands as soon as you can with a bacterial soap.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus survives on surfaces yet—it may be between hours and days.

claims.text: The symptoms of Covid-19 are a sore throat lasting 3 or 4 days. The virus then blends into nasal fluid, enters the trachea and then the lungs causing pneumonia. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing. The nasal congestion feels like you're drowning

claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia, and the symptoms may not come in this exact order or at these times. The NHS does not mention nasal congestion that ‘feels like drowning’ as a specific symptom for Covid-19.

claims.text: Drinking lots of water will eliminate the new coronavirus from your throat.

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. It is a common myth.

claims.text: Gargling water mixed with salt or vinegar eliminates the new coronavirus from your throat.

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.

claims.text: Coronavirus stays on fabric for 9 hours, so washing clothes or being exposed to the sun for two hours meets the purpose of killing it.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on fabric. There isn’t evidence that it can transmit from fabrics to people, though soiled clothing from Covid-19 patients should be washed normally.

claims.text: If the new coronavirus is exposed to a temperature of 26-27ºC it will be killed, as it does not live in hot regions. Also drinking hot water and sun exposure will do the trick and staying away from ice cream and cold food is advised.

claimReview.textualRating: There have been cases of Covid-19 in areas with warmer temperatures than this, and we don’t know what temperatures the virus can withstand. There’s no evidence that hot water and the sun will cure it or that staying away from cold food can prevent it.

claims.text: Coronavirus lives for 12 hours on metal surfaces.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on surfaces yet, it could be between hours and days.

claims.text: Coronavirus lives on the hands for 10 minutes, but can be prevented with alcohol hand sanitiser.

claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear how long the virus can ‘survive’ on hands, but hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol is a good second choice to washing your hands with soap and water.

claims.text: The new coronavirus is 400-500 micro and for this reason wide enough to be stopped by masks.

claimReview.textualRating: The virus is 50-200 nanometres wide, and a mask, although sometimes necessary, won’t guarantee that you don’t get Covid-19.

claims.text: The new coronavirus does not settle in the air but is grounded so it is not transmitted by air.

claimReview.textualRating: The virus can spread via sneeze and cough droplets that can move a short distance through the air and into someone else’s system.

claims.text: Gargling with warm and salt water kills germs on the tonsils and prevents them from leaking into the lungs.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence gargling with saline will cure or prevent Covid-19.

claims.text: China was the first place to have over 100,000 5G towers.

claimReview.textualRating: While it is true that China has over 100,000 towers, it is unclear if it was the first place to pass this number.

claims.text: Bill Gates created the new coronavirus and a vaccine for it.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The Bill Gates and Melinda Gates Foundation has funded a research institute that has a patent to a different coronavirus.  Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold, SARS and the new virus that causes Covid-19.

claims.text: Symptoms of Covid-19 include nausea, hair loss, bone marrow damage.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Symptoms have been reported as including fever, coughing and shortness of breath.

claims.text: 5G is harmful to humans.

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that 5G can harm people.

claims.text: The new coronavirus is actually the impact of 5G exposure.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect, the new coronavirus is a virus and there is no evidence that 5G is harmful to people’s health.

claims.text: "Take a few sips of water every 15 minutes at least ... drinking water or other liquids will wash" the coronavirus "down through your throat and into the stomach. Once there, your stomach acid will kill all the virus."

claimReview.title: Viral Social Media Posts Offer False Coronavirus Tips

claims.text: Coronavirus may have been genetically engineered for “efficient spreading in the human population,” a bombshell new study has claimed.

claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong and the study does not claim the new coronavirus has been genetically engineered. It simply compares the genome sequence of SARS-CoV-2 with other coronaviruses, and suggests a reason why it might be spreading relatively efficiently.

claims.text: If the new coronavirus gets into your mouth, drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through the oesophagus. Once they’re in the stomach, the acid will kill the virus. If you don't drink enough water more regularly, the virus can enter your windpipes and into the lungs.

claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Drinking water does not prevent an infection and there have been cases where the virus has survived in the stomach and affected people’s intestines.

claims.text: To test for the new coronavirus, take a deep breath and hold for more than 10 seconds. If you complete it successfully without coughing, discomfort, stuffiness or tightness it proves there is no fibrosis in the lungs, basically indicating no infection.

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this test can show if you have the new coronavirus.

claims.text: Using a hair dryer to breathe in hot air can cure COVID-19 and stop its spread.

claimReview.title: No, a Hair Dryer Won't Stop Coronavirus 17 March 2020 Fact Check ...

claims.text: Coronaviruses can live on surfaces for up to 28 days, so you should be careful if you receive a package from China.

claimReview.textualRating: There is currently no evidence that this virus can survive on surfaces that long. Most other coronaviruses do not. Current health advice suggests the risk of contracting the virus from a package is very low.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation (WHO) have advised people to use contactless payments instead of cash to reduce the risk of Covid-19 transmission.

claimReview.textualRating: The WHO advises the public to wash their hands after handling money, especially if handling or eating food. But they haven’t issued a warning about using banknotes.

claims.text: "Anybody that wants a test [for COVID-19] can get a test. That’s what the bottom line is. ... Anybody right now and yesterday — anybody that needs a test gets a test. We — they’re there. They have the tests. And the tests are beautiful. Anybody that needs a test gets a test."

claimReview.title: The Facts on Coronavirus Testing

claims.text: "[T]hey don't even have a test kit [for COVID-19]. A test kit to determine whether or not someone has the disease."

claimReview.title: The Facts on Coronavirus Testing

claims.text: A coronavirus vaccine for cows shows that the virus behind the current outbreak is not new.

claimReview.textualRating: This is a different coronavirus from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can affect a range of species.

claims.text: A list documents U.S. President Donald Trump's various statements about the spread of COVID-19 coronavirus disease.

claimReview.title: Is This Timeline of Trump's Coronavirus Responses Accurate?

claims.text: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold, not Covid-19.

claimReview.textualRating: These are the symptoms for the common cold, but they don’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses. Try not to drink liquids with ice.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can either protect you from or cure diseases caused by viruses.
There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can protect you from viruses.

claims.text: On fabric it can survive for 6-12 hours. normal laundry detergent will kill it.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence yet that the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way. Any soiled clothing should be thoroughly washed.

claims.text: Coronavirus pneumonia is a dry cough with no runny nose.

claimReview.textualRating: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.
Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: The symptoms of Covid-19 are that it first infects the throat, so you’ll have a sore throat lasting 3 or 4 days. The virus then blends into nasal fluid that enters the trachea and then the lungs causing pneumonia. This takes about 5 or 6 days. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing

claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia, and the symptoms may not come in this exact order or at these times.

claims.text: Wash your hands frequently as the virus can only live on your hands for 5-10 minutes.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can last on the skin, especially not down to the minute. But you should regularly wash your hands.
There is no evidence yet on how long the virus can survive on the skin. But it is important to regularly wash your hands.

claims.text: You should also gargle as a prevention. A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this works as a preventative or a cure for the virus.

claims.text: If it drops on a metal surface it will live for at least 12 hours - so if you come into contact with any metal surface - wash your hands as soon as you can with a bacterial soap.

claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus survives on surfaces yet—it may be between hours and days.
It’s not yet known exactly how long the virus survives on surfaces.

claims.text: This new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of just 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claims.text: If someone with the new coronavirus sneezes, it travels about 10 feet before it drops to the ground and is no longer airborne

claimReview.textualRating: How far the droplets spread from a sneeze depends on environmental factors, but it is likely to be several metres.
Environmental factors impact how far droplets from a sneeze can travel, but it is likely to be several metres.

claims.text: "To keep new cases from entering our shores, we will be suspending all travel from Europe to the United States for the next 30 days."

claimReview.title: FactChecking Trump's Coronavirus Address

claims.text: Coronavirus cases are "going very substantially down, not up."

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "It took Barack Obama until October of 2009 to declare Swine Flu a National Health Emergency. It began in April of ’09 but Obama waited until 20,000 people in the US had been hospitalized & 1,000+ had died."

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "We need the Wall more than ever" to stop the spread of coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "I closed down the borders to China and to other areas that are very badly affected and really having a lot of troubles ...against the advice of almost everybody.”

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "The Obama administration made a decision on testing and that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing, and we undid that decision a few days ago.”

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: Insurers "have agreed to waive all co-payments for coronavirus treatments"

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "Anybody that needs a test can have a test."

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "They’re going to have vaccines, I think, relatively soon."

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "You lose 27,000 people to the common flu.”

claimReview.title: Fact-Checking President Trump's Claims on the Coronavirus

claims.text: "We’ve gotten the highest poll numbers of anybody for this kind of thing.”

claims.text: "Nobody had ever even heard of Ebola or ever conceived of something where you basically — the people would disintegrate....The level of death with Ebola — you know, at the time, it was a virtual hundred percent.”

claims.text: “The United States is right now ranked by far No. 1 in the world for preparedness.”

claims.text: "[E]arly on in this crisis, we said — I said, among others, that, you know, you should get into China, get our experts there, we have the best in the world, get them in so we know what’s actually happening. There was no effort to do that.”

claimReview.title: Biden's False Claim on Trump's Response to Coronavirus

claims.text: Children can’t get the new coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: Children can get Covid-19 but there have been relatively few cases in children and in general, their symptoms tend to be milder.

claims.text: Eating bananas is a preventative against the COVID-19 coronavirus disease.

claimReview.title: Will Eating Bananas Prevent Coronavirus Infection?

claims.text: Breathing steam from a boiling pot of water will treat or cure a novel coronavirus infection
The World Health Organization “offered the [coronavirus] testing kits that they have available” but “we refused them.”

claimReview.title: Biden, Trump Wrong About WHO Coronavirus Tests

claims.text: The World Health Organization test for the new coronavirus "was a bad test."

claimReview.title: Biden, Trump Wrong About WHO Coronavirus Tests

claims.text: Colloidal silver solution can help with coronavirus
Drinking water or keeping your throat wet can stop you catching coronavirus

claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this

claims.text: The application of heat or heating your body can kill coronavirus

claimReview.textualRating: We don't have good enough evidence for this yet - but it's unlikely that applying heat to your body will stop you from catching coronavirus

claims.text: Garlic can prevent coronavirus

claimReview.textualRating: False - there's no evidence for this

claims.text: A "miracle mineral solution" (MMS) or drinking bleach can cure coronavirus
The Italian Prime Minister has said his country has exhausted all options to fight against the coronavirus pandemic and pleads to God to “rescue your people.”
Rashes are a symptom of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: No official advice lists rashes as a symptom of the new coronavirus.

claims.text: People describing themselves as Red Cross workers are knocking on doors of people's homes and selling what they claim are coronavirus home tests.

claimReview.title: No, Red Cross Is Not Offering Coronavirus Home Tests 19 March ...

claims.text: Genuine news report says Australian scientists found bananas prevent COVID-19
North Korea leader Kim Jong Un ordered his country's first COVID-19 patient to be shot dead.

claimReview.title: Did Kim Jong Un Order North Korea's First Coronavirus Patient To Be Executed?

claims.text: Cocaine and bleach can cure coronavirus

claimReview.title: Coronavirus cannot be cured by drinking bleach or snorting cocaine ...

claims.text: The WHO coronavirus test “was a bad test.”

claimReview.title: Donald Trump falsely says WHO coronavirus test 'was a bad test'

claims.text: "I think the 3.4% is really a false number," referring to the World Health Organization saying 3.4% of reported COVID-19 patients worldwide have died.

claimReview.title: Trump and the Coronavirus Death Rate

claims.text: “This is a pandemic. I felt it was a pandemic long before it was called a pandemic.”

claimReview.title: Trump and the Coronavirus Death Rate

claims.text: USA Today published a front-page article about the development of a COVID-19 vaccine the same day Kobe Bryant's death was reported.

claimReview.title: Did Coronavirus Vaccine Story Run Same Day as Reports of Kobe's ...

claims.text: "Gargling with warm water & salt or vinegar eliminates" the coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Gargling Water With Salt Won't 'Eliminate' Coronavirus

claims.text: Ginger a cure for novel coronavirus (COVID-19)
"Being exposed to the sun for two hours" kills the 2019 coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Sun exposure does not kill the coronavirus

claims.text: If the coronavirus gets in your mouth, "drinking water or other liquids will WASH them down through your esophagus and into the stomach. Once there in tummy ... your stomach ACID will kill all the virus."

claimReview.title: Drinking water does not prevent coronavirus infection

claims.text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson advocated for the UK to take Covid-19 “on the chin” and allow the disease to spread through the population.

claimReview.textualRating: The Prime Minister said this was a theory on how to deal with the virus, but said it would be better if we take all the measures we can to reduce the burden on the NHS during the peak of the disease.

claims.text: A bovine coronavirus vaccine, for cattle, is proof that the novel coronavirus isn't "new" and is evidence of "how much the media controls people."

claimReview.title: Cattle Vaccine Not Related to 2019 Novel Coronavirus

claims.text: Hand "sanitizer will do nothing for the coronavirus."

claimReview.title: Contrary to False Posts, Sanitizer Helpful Against Coronavirus

claims.text: "Nancy Pelosi wouldn’t release 8.5 billion for Coronavirus without abortion funding, so Trump went around her to declare a National Emergency and got 50 billion."

claimReview.title: False Claim That Pelosi Withheld Coronavirus Funds Over Abortion

claims.text: An MSNBC reporter said on air: "I hope enough people die from coronavirus that it harms Trump's reelection."

claimReview.title: Did MSNBC Reporter Say 'I Hope Coronavirus Kills People and ...

claims.text: The number of COVID-19 cases in the United States "are going very substantially down, not up.”

claimReview.title: FactChecking Trump's Coronavirus Press Conference

claims.text: Joseph Maldonado-Passage, better known as Joe Exotic of "Tiger King," has COVID-19 coronavirus disease.

claimReview.title: Does 'Tiger King' Joe Exotic Have Coronavirus?

claims.text: "We do have 19 out of our 50 states, to be reminded, that had early cases but have persistently low level of cases and, at this point, have less than 200 cases. So that’s almost 40% of the country with extraordinarily low numbers."

claimReview.title: Birx Spins 'Extraordinarily Low Numbers' of Coronavirus Cases

claims.text: Said of the coronavirus outbreak: "I just want to reiterate, because a lot of people have been asking, 'Well, what would have happened if we did nothing? Did nothing — we just rode it out.' ... And I think we got our most accurate study today, or certainly most comprehensive. Think of the number: 2.2 — potentially 2.2 million people if we did nothing."

claimReview.title: Trump and the Coronavirus Death Projections

claims.text: Coronavirus isn’t dangerous as it can be killed by Dettol products.

claimReview.textualRating: How dangerous the novel coronavirus is doesn’t relate to whether disinfectants work against it. Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold. Dettol has said its products haven’t been tested against the new virus yet.

claims.text: Dettol antiseptic spray says it kills coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: That is correct but that doesn’t refer to the new coronavirus (Covid-19) identified in Wuhan. Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold. Dettol has said its products haven’t been tested against the new virus yet.

claims.text: A vaccine for the new coronavirus has been created by US scientists and will be ready to use from next Sunday.

claimReview.textualRating: Whilst there are vaccines in development, it will likely be more than 18 months before they are ready to use. The image and videos accompanying the post are related to Covid-19 diagnostic tests, not vaccines.

claims.text: Says President Donald Trump made comments downplaying the coronavirus as the number of cases in the U.S. rose exponentially.

claimReview.title: Ad Watch: Priorities USA on Trump's coronavirus response

claims.text: "It looks like by April, you know in theory, when it gets a little warmer, [the new coronavirus] miraculously goes away — I hope that’s true."

claimReview.title: Will the New Coronavirus 'Go Away' in April?

claims.text: Jacob Rothschild owns a patent to coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no patent to the new coronavirus discovered recently in Wuhan.

claims.text: Pets carry no threat and do not carry the new coronavirus.

claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. At present, there’s no evidence that dogs and cats can be infected.

claims.text: "[T]he Obama administration made a decision on testing that turned out to be very detrimental to what we’re doing. And we undid that decision ... [W]e ended that rule very quickly."

claimReview.title: Trump's Misplaced Blame on Obama for Coronavirus Tests

claims.text: A patent for coronavirus was granted in 2018 to the Pirbright Institute UK, founded by Bill and Melinda Gates.

claimReview.textualRating: A patent for a different virus in the same family as the Wuhan virus was applied for by the Pirbright Institute, which receives part of its funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

claims.text: The coronavirus patent was applied for in 2015.

claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A company applied for a patent on a weakened version of a virus in the same family as the new Wuhan virus.

claims.text: Two authors predicted the coronavirus decades before the outbreak.

claimReview.textualRating: A 1980s sci-fi novel describes a disease called “Wuhan-400” that bears little similarity to the new Wuhan coronavirus. A book of “prophecies about the end of the world” written in 2008 predicted that a pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world in the year 2020.

claims.text: “Shands Hospital of Gainesville Florida has confirmed its first case of coronavirus.”

claimReview.title: Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida, hasn't confirmed a ...

claims.text: There are 59 positive Coronavirus cases in Nagpur along with 3 doctors one of whom is on ventilator.

claimReview.title: Fact check: Audio clip stating 59 positive coronavirus cases in ...

claims.text: CDC recommends people to shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Fact Check: No, US health body has not recommended shaving ...

claims.text: An audio message lists five ways people can prevent the novel coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Audio shared on Facebook Messenger spreads false information ...

claims.text: Dr. Usman Riyaz from Delhi died of Coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Fact Check: No Delhi doctor died due to coronavirus

claims.text: Drinking hot water with lemons will cure or prevent COVID-19; drinking hot water with lemons and sodium bicarbonate will “alkalize the immune system” and cure or prevent COVID-19.

claims.text: Covid-19 starts with a sore throat lasting 3-4 days. It then blends into a nasal fluid that enters the trachea and the lungs, causing pneumonia, which takes about 5 or 6 days. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing. The nasal congestion makes you feel like you’re drowning.

claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia. The symptoms may not come in this order or at these times. There have been no reports of sufferers experiencing nasal congestion that makes them feel they are drowning.

claims.text: The new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claims.text: You should gargle as a prevention with salt in warm water.

claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence this will prevent or cure the virus.

claims.text: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold.

claimReview.textualRating: These are the symptoms for the common cold, but they don’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: A book published in 1981 said that in 2020 a severe pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world, and calling it “Wuhan-400”.

claimReview.textualRating: These lines are from two different books: one is from a book of predictions by a psychic published in 2008 that predicted a pneumonia-like illness, and “Wuhan-400” is a fictional disease from a sci-fi book published in 1981 that bears little similarity to the new Wuhan coronavirus.

claims.text: Social media users are questioning the origins of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus as it continues to spread after discovering that some Dettol cleaning products “kill” the human coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Dettol effective against known strains, not 2019 Novel Coronavirus
claimReview.textualRating: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be a mixture of true and false information. Coronavirus, which was first identified in the mid-1960s, is an umbrella term used to describe different strains of the illness ranging from the common cold to SARS coronavirus and MERS coronavirus and also the 2019 Novel Coronavirus. The Dettol Surface Cleanser, which lists Human Coronavirus as a microbe the product is able to eliminate, is produced by Dettol UK. The company says they have not tested their products on the 2019 Novel Coronavirus and there is no evidence at this stage they would be able to kill the new strain.

claims.text: Coronavirus killed 1,12,000 people and infected 28 lakh in China.

claims.text: As cases of the 2019 Novel Coronavirus continue to climb, information on the number of people infected and the World Health Organisation’s (WHO) response to the outbreak continues to spread on social media.

claimReview.title: The WHO has not labelled coronavirus a plague and the virus has ...
claimReview.textualRating: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the Instagram post to be false. While the WHO has declared the 2019 coronavirus outbreak as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern, it has not deemed the outbreak as a “plague”. Also the number of infections and deaths globally are far below the numbers claimed in the post. Although the Instagram user labelled the claim in their first upload with “cap”, potentially indicating the post was false, many users appear unaware the post contains false information.
